page.name: Pass vs Don't Pass Line Probability Simulation

children.value: Craps is a popular dice game played in casinos, and one of the most fundamental bets in the game is the Pass Line bet. In this bet, the player is betting on the shooter to roll a 7 or 11 on the come-out roll or to establish a point number and then roll that number before rolling a 7.

There is also a Don't Pass Line bet available in the game, which is the opposite of the Pass Line bet. In this bet, the player is betting against the shooter, hoping that the shooter will roll a 2, 3, or 12 on the come-out roll, or roll a 7 before rolling the point number.
So, which bet has a higher probability of winning, the Pass Line or the Don't Pass Line? Let's take a closer look at the probabilities involved.

First, let's consider the Pass Line bet. The come-out roll can result in any of the following outcomes: 2, 3, 7, 11, or 12. The probability of rolling a 2, 3, or 12 is 1/36 + 2/36 + 1/36 = 4/36 = 1/9, or approximately 11.1%. The probability of rolling a 7 or 11 is 6/36 + 2/36 = 8/36 = 2/9, or approximately 22.2%. Once a point number is established, the probability of rolling that number before rolling a 7 is determined by the number of ways that number can be rolled compared to the number of ways a 7 can be rolled. For example, if the point number is 6, there are 5 ways to roll a 6 and only 6 ways to roll a 7, so the probability of rolling a 6 before a 7 is 5/11, or approximately 45.5%.

Now, let's consider the Don't Pass Line bet. The come-out roll can result in any of the following outcomes: 2, 3, 7, 11, or 12. The probability of rolling a 2 or 3 is 1/36 + 2/36 = 3/36 = 1/12, or approximately 8.3%. The probability of rolling a 7 or 11 is 6/36 + 2/36 = 8/36 = 2/9, or approximately 22.2%. The probability of rolling a 12 is 1/36, or approximately 2.8%. Once a point number is established, the probability of rolling a 7 before rolling that number is determined by the number of ways a 7 can be rolled compared to the number of ways that number can be rolled. For example, if the point number is 6, there are 6 ways to roll a 7 and only 5 ways to roll a 6, so the probability of rolling a 7 before a 6 is 6/11, or approximately 54.5%.

From these calculations, we can see that the Pass Line bet has a higher probability of winning on the come-out roll, with a probability of approximately 33.3% compared to the Don't Pass Line's probability of approximately 30.6%. However, once a point number is established, the Don't Pass Line bet has a higher probability of winning, with a probability of approximately 54.5% compared to the Pass Line's probability of approximately 45.5%.
